hints_html:
The simplest differential equation we can solve for is

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dy}{dt} = ky\end{aligned}\]

which gives the solution

\[\begin{aligned} y(t) = y(0)e^{kt}.\end{aligned}\]

How can we make our current equation look like this?

Set

\[\begin{aligned} y(t) = T(t) - 19\end{aligned}\]

Then use the hint to get the differential equation.

The last step is to solve for k using the given information.
hints_latex: The last step is to solve for \emph{k} using the given information.
hints_raw:
The simplest differential equation we can solve for is

<math>
\begin{align}
\frac{dy}{dt} = ky
\end{align}
</math>

which gives the solution

<math>
\begin{align}
y(t) = y(0)e^{kt}.
\end{align}
</math>

How can we make our current equation look like this?
Set 

<math>
\begin{align}
y(t) = T(t) - 19
\end{align}
</math>

Then use the hint to get the differential equation.
The last step is to solve for ''k'' using the given information.
question: 2 (b)
sols_html:
Proceeding as in the hints, let

\(\displaystyle y(t) = T(t) - 19\)

Then, Newton’s law of cooling reads

\(\displaystyle \frac{dy}{dt} = \frac{dT}{dt} = k(T(t) - 19) = ky(t)\)

Solving this differential equation gives

\(\displaystyle y(t) = y(0)e^{kt}\)

In terms of T and using the initial condition \(T(0) = 3\), we have

\(\displaystyle T(t) - 19 = (T(0) - 19)e^{kt} = (3-19)e^{kt} = -16e^{kt}\)

After 30 minutes, we know \(T(30) = 11\) and so

\(\displaystyle -16e^{30k} = T(30)-19 = 11-19 = -8\)

Solving for k by isolating and taking logarithms gives

\(\displaystyle k = \frac{\ln(1/2)}{30} = -\frac{\ln(2)}{30}\)

We want to find the temperature after 90 minutes and so

\[\begin{aligned} T(90) - 19 &= -16e^{90\cdot(-\ln(2))/30} \\ &= -16e^{-3\ln(2)} \\ &= -16e^{\ln(2^{-3})} \\ &= -16(1/8) \\ &= -2\end{aligned}\]

and thus \(T(90) = 19-2 = 17\) degrees celsius
sols_latex:
Proceeding as in the hints, let

$\displaystyle y(t) = T(t) - 19$

Then, Newton's law of cooling reads

$\displaystyle \frac{dy}{dt} = \frac{dT}{dt} = k(T(t) - 19) = ky(t)$

Solving this differential equation gives

$\displaystyle y(t) = y(0)e^{kt}$

In terms of \emph{T} and using the initial condition $T(0) = 3$, we have

$\displaystyle T(t) - 19 = (T(0) - 19)e^{kt} = (3-19)e^{kt} = -16e^{kt}$

After 30 minutes, we know $T(30) = 11$ and so

$\displaystyle -16e^{30k} = T(30)-19 = 11-19 = -8$

Solving for \emph{k} by isolating and taking logarithms gives

$\displaystyle k = \frac{\ln(1/2)}{30} = -\frac{\ln(2)}{30}$

We want to find the temperature after 90 minutes and so

\begin{align*}
T(90) - 19  &= -16e^{90\cdot(-\ln(2))/30} \\
&= -16e^{-3\ln(2)} \\
&= -16e^{\ln(2^{-3})} \\
&= -16(1/8) \\
&= -2
\end{align*}

and thus $T(90) = 19-2 = 17$ degrees celsius
sols_raw:
Proceeding as in the hints, let

<math>
\displaystyle
y(t) = T(t) - 19
</math>

Then, Newton's law of cooling reads

<math>
\displaystyle
\frac{dy}{dt} = \frac{dT}{dt} = k(T(t) - 19) = ky(t)
</math>

Solving this differential equation gives

<math>
\displaystyle
y(t) = y(0)e^{kt}
</math>

In terms of ''T'' and using the initial condition <math> T(0) = 3 </math>, we have

<math>
\displaystyle
T(t) - 19 = (T(0) - 19)e^{kt} = (3-19)e^{kt} = -16e^{kt}
</math>

After 30 minutes, we know <math>T(30) = 11 </math> and so

<math>
\displaystyle
-16e^{30k} = T(30)-19 = 11-19 = -8
</math>

Solving for ''k'' by isolating and taking logarithms gives

<math>
\displaystyle
k = \frac{\ln(1/2)}{30} = -\frac{\ln(2)}{30}
</math>

We want to find the temperature after 90 minutes and so

<math>
\begin{align}
T(90) - 19  &= -16e^{90\cdot(-\ln(2))/30} \\
&= -16e^{-3\ln(2)} \\
&= -16e^{\ln(2^{-3})} \\
&= -16(1/8) \\
&= -2
\end{align}
</math>

and thus <math> T(90) = 19-2 = 17 </math> degrees celsius
statement_html:
Full-Solution Problems. In questions 2-8, justify your answers and show all your work. If a box is provided, write your final answer there. Simplification of answers is not required unless explicitly requested.

When an apple is taken from a refrigerator, its temperature is \(3^{\circ}C\). After 30 minutes in a \(19^{\circ}C\) room, its temperature is \(11^{\circ}C\).

Find the temperature of the apple 90 minutes after it is taken from the refrigerator, expressed as an integer number of degrees Celsius.

statement_raw:
Full-Solution Problems. In questions 2-8, justify your answers and show all your work. If a box is provided, write your final answer there. Simplification of answers is not required unless explicitly requested.

When an apple is taken from a refrigerator, its temperature is <math> 3^{\circ}C </math>. After 30 minutes in a <math> 19^{\circ}C </math> room, its temperature is <math> 11^{\circ}C</math>.

Find the temperature of the apple 90 minutes after it is taken from the refrigerator, expressed as an integer number of degrees Celsius.
